summary: This is an email chain from May 2019 between FBI personnel and a Southern District of New York (SDNY) Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the location and transfer of physical case files from the Florida FBI's Epstein investigation to New York. The SDNY is urgently requesting the files, which have been sought since December 2018, and proposes using a third-party vendor for scanning.

persons.name: SSA - FBI New York
persons.context: The recipient of an email update regarding the status of locating and transferring Epstein investigation files from Florida to New York.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The author pushing for the transfer of Epstein case files from Florida to the SDNY, providing examples of past cases where third-party vendors were used for scanning sensitive documents.

connections.person2: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Communicating and coordinating regarding the transfer and handling of Epstein investigation case files from the FBI's Florida office to the SDNY.

events.title: SDNY Case File Review in Florida
events.description: SDNY personnel visited the Florida FBI office and identified case files and other boxes related to the Epstein investigation.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Urgent Request for Epstein Case Files
events.description: The SDNY applies significant pressure on the FBI to locate and transfer the physical Epstein investigation files from Florida to New York, a process that had been ongoing for six months.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: The SDNY had been trying to obtain the physical Epstein investigation case files from the Florida FBI since at least December 2018, making it a six-month process by May 2019.

Florida FBI had previously located the files and made them available for the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) weeks prior, but there was renewed confusion about their location and transfer status.

The SDNY proposed having the files sent directly to them or a vendor for scanning, citing experience with handling sensitive documents in other cases, but the FBI's legal counsel and ASAC were initially opposed to direct transfer to the USAO.
The email chain reveals internal bureaucratic delays and coordination challenges between different FBI field offices and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding a high-profile investigation.
